rawLines.text: [Music]
welcome to CSX week 3 Uh this is
infrastructure week and we uh have a lot
of great things planned We'll start uh
the morning with a with a talk by uh our
general partner Ali Yaha and uh Shriram
Kanan the founder of Igen layer Please
join me in welcoming Ali and Shir
Shirram thank you so much for joining us
today Thank you so much Ali My pleasure
Great to to talk about what you're up to
and uh and also about your journey and
and how you've got gotten to this point
in kind of the arc of your uh career as
a founder But let's start maybe just
with a big picture about IEN layer Uh
what is your latest framing for the
problem that I layer solves ign layer
What is IGEN layer igen in German for
your own your own layer Anybody can
build whatever they want The core thesis
of IG layer is open innovation So what
is open innovation so if you think about
decentralized networks like Bitcoin you
can think of these networks as made of
many different layers So there's a layer
of security for example in Bitcoin pro
work layer of security Then there's a
layer of consensus is we all agree on
something that what's the next block and
then there's a layer of execution for
example in Bitcoin it's bitcoin script
and on top of it is the application in
bitcoin it's like send and receive
bitcoins so all these four layers are
bundled together in the bitcoin
blockchain so I think of you know
nowadays people talk about app chains
right bitcoin is the first app chain
right it's integrated all the way up and
this is typically how any industry
starts you you have like a fully
integrated system because specialization
is not possible when you're inventing
something off the bat And what Ethereum
did is expand uh or modularize the
system so that anybody can build
applications So the application layer
becomes modularized So anybody can build
applications and deploy them And what
does this do you know it's a really
interesting phenomenon I call the
separation of trust and innovation So
the blockchain is supplying trust and
anybody can now supply innovation like I
can write a piece of code and then
deploy it on top of the Ethereum
blockchain and you don't need to know
who I am where I'm from you know or
anything You can just trust that that
system works as expected because
Ethereum's underwriting trust into it So
this is a huge deal and uh you know one
of the stories I like to say is you know
one of our uh teammates now Agajesh he
was a 13-year-old kid in India from a
random like place he wrote this DeFi
program for you know trading
and you know in without blockchains
there's no chance anybody would trust
this kid and put like a penny into it
but there's $7 million that was locked
into his contract and people trading
because they don't need to know who
Gajesh is or where he came from or what
his anticidence are The trust is
underwritten by the blockchain This is
awesome So opens up so much
permissionless innovation That's why we
have the whole pseudonmous economy like
the idea that I I can be a nobody and
still build systems that are highly
trusted that only JP Morgan could build
in yesterday But that is not in our view
enough open innovation because what's
happening is you can anybody can build
applications that can fit on top of the
Ethereum structure which is the security
model the consensus model the execution
model the EVM and then build on top
Ethereum itself took one more step
further to do the roll-up era where said
anybody can now build new execution
environments that can go on top of this
common security and so now like a rollup
is basically an execution environment
you build that you prove to the Ethereum
blockchain that you're running correctly
but now people can build different kinds
of execution environments not just
solidity and EVM but you can build more
you can build all kinds of other things
web assembly and rust and everything
else but even that has a consensus
bottleneck because the way nodes come
into consensus and then create your
final solutions are all determined by
the Ethereum blockchain So you have the
consensus layer is shared layer is
designed so that you it's just raw
decentralized trust You have a group of
nodes which stake and these nodes stake
and then you create an arbitrary service
and for this let's say the service is I
want to get consensus on AI inference So
these nodes run this AI inference
software and then arrive at whatever
consensus protocol you write and then
like give you the outputs So I think of
this as the progressive deepening of the
amount of permissionless innovation
that's available So from Bitcoin where
you know anybody can participate in the
network but nobody can program it to
Ethereum where anybody can write smart
contracts to the rollupcentric era where
anybody can write execution environments
to layer where you can write any crypto
service you want on top of a common
decentralized trust network That's a
beautiful way to explain it Well to
summarize it so like Bitcoin is this
vertically integrated blockchain that's
almost entirely application specific It
has one purpose and that is to serve as
a kind of store of value It originally
intended to be a blockchain for payments
In the end it ended up being more like a
kind of digital gold and that is the one
thing that it does very well Ethereum
modularized a little bit further by
decoupling u sort of the security aspect
uh from the application So it introduced
a programming language Now you can write
all sorts of different kinds of
applications as long as you conform to
the one specific virtual machine and
execution like the runtime that Ethereum
puts forward like it has to be EVM and
that's kind of the constraint the set of
constraints that you have to operate
under and you also just have to take the
consensus uh implementation that
Ethereum provides and so I layer goes
even further and decouples like the
security aspect the security that the
validators provide to the network from
consensus such that you can now build
your own uh consensus layer and
therefore also build your own execution
environment have your own virtual
machine uh which really kind of unlocks
the design base and makes it much
broader for certain things that maybe
don't fit into the EVM You can now you
can now sort of build something that
would normally would would require you
to build an entire layer 1 blockchain
from scratch Now you can kind of more
easily tap into the security that
Ethereum might offer and and build it in
a way that's much much more much easier
using layer Is that like a good that's a
that's a great that's a great summary of
what we're trying to do So services
built on top of a layer we call them as
actively validated services and it's
chosen carefully like it's a service
that is built on top of a decentralized
trust network and the mental model that
we want to create is not like hey
whenever you want to build a new thing
you have to build a chain A chain is
basically an ordered ledger which has
some kind of execution attached to it
But a service could be like a
co-processor You're sitting on a
blockchain and then you make a call and
then it returns you an answer It could
run it based on computation It could run
it based on storing data It could run a
service based on fetching data from the

service it could be a chain but it
doesn't have to be a chain It's just a
service that provides something narrow
And you know one analogy is to the inb 2
and cloud You have the idea of software
as a service right so you build a
service you say hey you know here's a
piece of code I throw it on top of AWS
and it's running this code and anybody
who wants to use it just have subscribe
to this fee model and then use this
particular service and when you're
building an application today on cloud
you just go and usually concatenate a
bunch of software as a service solutions
and then only write the things that are
not available you know for your
particular application So you don't have
to write your own database You don't
have to write your own login You don't
have to write your own payment solution
You use stripe You use MongoDB You use
Oath And then you put them together to
like build whatever applications you
want That's how we got so much open
innovation in in the web world Anybody
could now like spin spin out like a
website like Shopify makes it easy for
you to run your own e-commerce store All
this kind of stuff We want to bring the
same amount of permissionless innovation
to crypto Yeah Another metaphor which
I'm curious I'm curious if you would
agree with this this way of framing uh
what I layer is just sort of
historically in the world of computing
there was this whole trend of

where now as a developer you you can

maybe AVS are somewhat analogous to

it's dangerous to think by analogy but I

end nodes need to put up so much stake
They need to come to consensus in this

one of the things that we do want to do

So this these kinds of like metahistics
